text: EXXON COMPANY, U.S.A.
label: TITLE

text: IBLA 88-181
label: BODY

text: Decided February 21, 1990
label: BODY

text: Appeal from a decision of the Deputy Director, Minerals Management Service, affirming an order
label: BODY

text: assessing charges for erroneous reporting.  MMS 87-0222-O&G.
label: BODY

text: Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.
label: BODY

text: Administrative Practice--Administrative Procedure: Decisions
label: BODY

text: When issuing a formal decision one must do more than ensure that the
label: BODY

text: decision is supported by a rational basis.  The basis for that decision
label: BODY

text: must be stated
label: BODY

text: in the written decision and demonstrated in the administrative record
label: BODY

text: accompanying the decision.  The recipient of the decision deserves a
label: BODY

text: reasoned and factual explanation of the rationale for the decision, and
label: BODY

text: must be given some basis for understanding it and accepting it or,
label: BODY

text: alternatively, for appealing and disputing it.
label: BODY

text: Administrative Procedure: Generally--Federal Oil and Gas Royalty
label: BODY

text: Management Act of 1982: Generally--Federal Oil and Gas Royalty
label: BODY

text: Management Act of 1982: Assessments--Oil and Gas Leases: Royalties:
label: BODY

text: Generally--Regulations: Generally--Regulations: Applicability--
label: BODY

text: Regulations: Interpretation
label: BODY

text: A regulation should be sufficiently clear that there is no basis for an oil
label: BODY

text: and gas lessee's noncompliance with the regulation before that regulation
label: BODY

text: is interpreted to the detriment of a lessee.  If a regulation is ambiguous,
label: BODY

text: any doubt as to its meaning should be resolved favorably to the lessee.
label: BODY

text: The need for clarity is even more imperative when MMS attempts to
label: BODY

text: base a significant monetary assessment on a lessee's failure to properly
label: BODY

text: apply provisions of its Oil and Gas Payor Handbook, because that
label: BODY

text: Handbook lacks the force and effect of
label: BODY

text: law enjoyed by a statute or regulation.
label: BODY

text: APPEARANCES:  Salvatore J. Casamassima, Esq., Houston, Texas, for appel- lant; Peter J. Schaumberg,
label: BODY

text: Esq., Geoffrey Heath, Esq., and Howard W. Chalker, Esq., Office of the Solicitor, U.S. Department of the
label: BODY

text: Interior, Washington, D.C., for the Minerals Management Service.
label: BODY

text: 113 IBLA 199
label: BODY

text: IBLA 88-181
label: BODY

text: OPINION BY ADMINISTRATIVE JUDGE MULLEN
label: BODY

text: Exxon Company, U.S.A. (Exxon), has appealed from a decision of the Deputy Director, Minerals
label: BODY

text: Management Service (MMS), dated October 5, 1987, affirming a $10,000 assessment for erroneous reporting
label: BODY

text: on Exxon's June 1986 Form MMS-2014, Report of Sales and Royalty Remittance.
label: BODY

text: At the outset of this decision we must note that the record submitted by MMS on appeal is not the
label: BODY

text: complete, official file in this dispute.  MMS has not submitted Exxon's June 1986 Form MMS-2014, or a
label: BODY

text: complete copy of Royalty Rejected Line Detail Report No. ATL 152R, documents central to the dispute now
label: BODY

text: before us.  The MMS field report and MMS' Answer do shed some light upon what transpired, but, in the
label: BODY

text: absence of the complete file, some details of the disputed transaction are left to speculation. 1/
label: BODY

text: Oil and gas lessees are required to file monthly production reports with MMS.  The reports filed
label: BODY

text: are on forms prepared by MMS, and require a listing of various transactions as line item entries, using
label: BODY

text: various numeric codes, called "transaction codes" (TCs).  MMS also requires the use of the report form for
label: BODY

text: entries intended to correct entries on previous reports, and a numeric code is also used to describe the nature
label: BODY

text: of any line item entry that makes adjustments.  These entries are called "adjustment rea-
label: BODY

text: son codes" (ARCs)  Use of these codes presumably facilitates computerized processing of production data.
label: BODY

text: The dispute now before us arose from the manner in which Exxon completed Form MMS-2014
label: BODY

text: in June 1986 when it made line item entries to adjust previously reported transportation allowances
label: BODY

text: (allowable deductions).  Evidently, MMS had previously approved a tentative transportation allowance, with
label: BODY

text: the understanding that necessary adjustments would be made when actual costs were determined.
label: BODY

text: Apparently, Exxon assembled transportation cost data, and, in the June 1986 report, it "reversed" the
label: BODY

text: previously reported tentative allowance (presumably by adding an amount equal to the tentative allowance
label: BODY

text: previously deducted) and replaced it with a corrected transportation allowance based on actual costs. 2/  This
label: BODY

text: adjustment was evidently noted with the correct TC and ARC, as MMS has had no problem with the manner
label: BODY

text: in which Exxon reported this adjustment.
label: BODY

text: 1/  MMS is reminded of its obligation to submit the complete, original administrative record to this Board
label: BODY

text: when an appeal is filed, and that failure to comply may result in our vacating its decision as unsupported
label: BODY

text: by the evidence.  Dugan Production Corp., 103 IBLA 362, 364 (1988), and cases cited therein.  We note that
label: BODY

text: despite the difficulty experienced
label: BODY

text: when attempting to determine what actually transpired in this case, it is unnecessary for us to take further
label: BODY

text: steps to overcome MMS' failure to submit a complete record.  The MMS decision must be reversed on other
label: BODY

text: grounds.
label: BODY

text: 2/  It is not clear whether Exxon revised an earlier report for June 1986, or made entries in a June 1986 report
label: BODY

text: to adjust entries on previous report(s).  It appears that the latter procedure was used.
label: BODY

text: 113 IBLA 200
label: BODY

text: IBLA 88-181
label: BODY

text: The problem arose because the June 1986 report also contained line item entries in which Exxon
label: BODY

text: had evidently reversed its previously reported gross royalty and royalty-in-kind figures for the same time
label: BODY

text: periods and replaced them with identical figures.  Exxon listed these entries using TC 01 (royalty due) and
label: BODY

text: TC 06 (royalty-in-kind) to describe the trans- actions and ARC 34 (adjustments for allowances) on the report
label: BODY

text: to explain
label: BODY

text: the adjustment.
label: BODY

text: MMS' computer balked at accepting the MMS-2014 report form sub-
label: BODY

text: mitted by Exxon because of Exxon's use of the ARC 34 entries, and generated Royalty Rejected Line Detail
label: BODY

text: Report No. ATL 152R.  The report identified 1,365 line item entries as being erroneous.  By demand letter
label: BODY

text: and bill
label: BODY

text: for collection, Invoice No. 75760111, both dated December 11, 1986, MMS assessed Exxon $10,000 for
label: BODY

text: 1,365 erroneous reports on Exxon's Form MMS-2014 for the June 1986 reporting period.  MMS enclosed
label: BODY

text: the Royalty Rejected Line Detail Report, upon which MMS circled each line which contained at least one
label: BODY

text: reporting error.  The following errors were cited by MMS:  "1.  [t]he use of adjustment reason codes that
label: BODY

text: were incompatible with the transaction codes used (e.g., using adjustment reason code 34 with transaction
label: BODY

text: codes 01 and 06); and 2. [r]eporting unnecessary lines with no quantities and values."  Although the
label: BODY

text: regulations then in effect provided for the assessment of $10 per line for each line containing one or more
label: BODY

text: payor errors (in this case $13,650), MMS charged Exxon $10,000, the maximum erroneous reporting
label: BODY

text: assessment permitted.
label: BODY

text: Exxon appealed this assessment to the Director, MMS.  In its appeal
label: BODY

text: to the Director, Exxon explained that the alleged errors resulted from adjustments it made to its tentative
label: BODY

text: transportation allowance figures following MMS' approval of its actual transportation costs for its California
label: BODY

text: Hondo lease.  Exxon argued that it had selected ARC 34 by following the
label: BODY

text: 1982 MMS Oil and Gas Payor Handbook (Handbook).  The Handbook instructions stated that ARC 34
label: BODY

text: should be used to adjust royalties as a result
label: BODY

text: of a retroactive allowance determination made by MMS, and that ARC 38,
label: BODY

text: the code MMS determined to be appropriate, should be used to adjust line entries previously reported with
label: BODY

text: coding or typographical errors.  Exxon further asserted that it had never been notified that ARC 34 was
label: BODY

text: incompatible with TC 01 and TC 06.
label: BODY

text: By decision dated October 5, 1987, the Deputy Director, MMS, denied Exxon's appeal.  He first
label: BODY

text: noted that a completed Form MMS-2014 must accompany all royalty payments to MMS.  He also indicated
label: BODY

text: that 30 CFR 218.40(b) (1986) provides for an assessment of $10 for each report which is completed
label: BODY

text: incorrectly, and that 30 CFR 218.40(c) (1986) defines a report as each line on a Form MMS-2014.  He
label: BODY

text: further found that Exxon's adjustments using ARC 34 in conjunction with TC 01 and TC 06 had been
label: BODY

text: rejected by the MMS exception processing system because ARC 34, as an adjustment to allowances,
label: BODY

text: is "incompatible" with TC 01 and TC 06, which are used for royalty transactions and not allowance
label: BODY

text: transactions.
label: BODY

text: 113 IBLA 201
label: BODY

text: IBLA 88-181
label: BODY

text: The Deputy Director continued:
label: BODY

text: The Appellant states that the MMS Payor Handbook does not explain this
label: BODY

text: incompatibility and that Exxon has never been notified that the use of ARC 34 for this
label: BODY

text: kind of reporting is incorrect.
label: BODY

text: The MMS Fiscal Accounting Division, in the field report on this appeal
label: BODY

text: prepared pursuant to 30 CFR 290.3(b) (1986), states that Exxon's errors were
label: BODY

text: avoidable because the adjustments made by Exxon (the reversals of TC 01 and 06)
label: BODY

text: were unwarranted and unnecessary.  The Fiscal Accounting Division further states that
label: BODY

text: Exxon was notified in November 1984 that this type of reporting was inappropriate.
label: BODY

text: The record supports the finding that Exxon had been notified of the
label: BODY

text: incompatibility of TC 01 and ARC 34.
label: BODY

text: Based on the record before me, I conclude the Fiscal Accounting Division acted
label: BODY

text: correctly with respect to the subject assessment.  The Appellant has offered no
label: BODY

text: arguments which would justify the waiver of these charges.  Accordingly, the subject
label: BODY

text: appeal is denied.
label: BODY

text: (Decision at 2).
label: BODY

text: In its statement of reasons (SOR), Exxon initially asks the Board to disregard the Deputy
label: BODY

text: Director's conclusion that the record supports the finding that Exxon had been notified of the incompatibility
label: BODY

text: of ARC 34 and TC 01 and TC 06.  This request derives from MMS' failure to provide a copy of the Fiscal
label: BODY

text: Accounting Division field report to Exxon or refer to any document of record supporting the MMS
label: BODY

text: notification claim.
label: BODY

text: Exxon also repeats the arguments it presented in its appeal to the Director.  Exxon notes that its
label: BODY

text: royalty reporting consists of two components--valuation and transportation allowances--and that the asserted
label: BODY

text: errors stem from its retroactive adjustment of the transportation allowance for
label: BODY

text: its Hondo lease.  Exxon then explains that when it made the transportation allowance adjustments on Form
label: BODY

text: MMS-2014, it attempted to set out the transportation adjustments in a straightforward manner, using ARC
label: BODY

text: 34 with the basic valuation lines TC 01 and TC 06.  Exxon asserts that there are no regulations, guidelines,
label: BODY

text: directives, or notices of any kind supporting the MMS position that ARC 34 cannot be used on
label: BODY

text: non-transportation lines, and that Exxon should have used ARC 38.
label: BODY

text: Exxon argues that the only written guidance for proper ARC designation was the 1982 Handbook
label: BODY

text: and that the instructions in the Handbook support its use of ARC 34.  Exxon elaborates:
label: BODY

text: 113 IBLA 202
label: BODY

text: IBLA 88-181
label: BODY

text: As stated in Appendix B.3 [3/] of the Handbook * * *, the MMS instructs that [ARC]
label: BODY

text: "34" is to be used "to adjust royalties as a result of a retroactive allowance
label: BODY

text: determination by [MMS]."  Nowhere does it state that the MMS prohibits the use of
label: BODY

text: the
label: BODY

text: code to adjustments made to valuation lines.  In fact, code "34" appears to be in
label: BODY

text: accordance with the instructions and is the most suitable code for retroactive
label: BODY

text: transportation adjustments of the type made.  In contrast, [ARC] "38" is ill-suited for
label: BODY

text: that type of adjustment.  The instructions for code "38" state that it is to be used "to
label: BODY

text: adjust line entries that were previously reported with coding or typographical errors
label: BODY

text: when the adjustment does not result in the payment of additional royalties."
label: BODY

text: (Emphasis supplied.)  Coding or typographical errors were clearly not the genesis of
label: BODY

text: the transportation allowance adjustments and it would be inappropriate, if not
label: BODY

text: incorrect, to use code "38" for such adjustments.  Code "34" best reflects that type of
label: BODY

text: adjustment, not code "38".
label: BODY

text: Thus, the only written guidance on the subject contradicts the position of the
label: BODY

text: MMS taken in this appeal.  Even if the MMS had revised its position on the proper
label: BODY

text: method of making the adjustment, there is nothing in the record that would indicate the
label: BODY

text: Payor Handbook was not providing the proper guidance.  The only rebuttal the MMS
label: BODY

text: offers is that it allegedly gave Exxon verbal notice of its error more than two years
label: BODY

text: prior to the incorrect adjustment.  Even if such a verbal contact had been made, it does
label: BODY

text: not pass muster under the Administrative Procedure Act as adequate notice of policy,
label: BODY

text: the violation of which carried a potential $10,000 penalty.  At the very least the MMS
label: BODY

text: should have sent a letter to Exxon in 1984 clarifying its interpretation
label: BODY

text: of the appropriate adjustment reason code.  [Emphasis in original.]
label: BODY

text: (SOR at 2-3).
label: BODY

text: Exxon concludes that the assessments for reporting errors based on
label: BODY

text: the use of the incorrect ARC should be rescinded, and that the assessments, at most, should be confined to
label: BODY

text: those lines containing no reported values or quantities.  Exxon further asserts that the $10,000 assessment
label: BODY

text: is grossly excessive in relation to the administrative inconvenience the errors caused MMS.  Exxon requests
label: BODY

text: that the Deputy Director's decision be reversed and the $10,000 tendered in payment of the assessment be
label: BODY

text: refunded.
label: BODY

text: In its answer, MMS describes its practice after a payor requests a transportation allowance:
label: BODY

text: The MMS grants a tentative allowance which the payor uses on a monthly basis until
label: BODY

text: actual cost data are available.  Actual cost data subsequently are used by the payor and
label: BODY

text: MMS to compute an actual transportation allowance.  Once an actual allowance is
label: BODY

text: 3/  The descriptions of the adjustment reason codes are actually found
label: BODY

text: in Appendix B.4 of the 1982 Handbook.
label: BODY

text: 113 IBLA 203
label: BODY

text: IBLA 88-181
label: BODY

text: granted, the payor reverses its previously reported transportation allowance entries,
label: BODY

text: which were based on the tentative allowance, and enters the approved transportation
label: BODY

text: allowance.
label: BODY

text: (Answer at 2).
label: BODY

text: MMS states that Exxon's report correctly set out the adjustments to its transportation allowance
label: BODY

text: by setting out the transportation allowance based on actual costs and reversing the tentative transportation
label: BODY

text: allowance, but was in error because Exxon had also reversed its royalty lines (TC 01 and TC 06) and
label: BODY

text: reentered those lines exactly as it had reversed them.  MMS contends that the whole assessment could have
label: BODY

text: been avoided because there was no reason to reverse and reenter those royalty lines, because the gross royalty
label: BODY

text: value was not changed by the transportation allowance adjustments.  MMS explains that the erroneous
label: BODY

text: reporting assessment was made because Exxon used ARC 34, an incorrect code, to justify the adjustments
label: BODY

text: when it unnecessarily adjusted its royalty lines (TC 01 and TC 06).  MMS states that it rejected Exxon's
label: BODY

text: contention that it used the correct code because TC 01
label: BODY

text: and TC 06 are royalty transactions which are incompatible with a code for allowance transactions.  MMS
label: BODY

text: explains the inconvenience resulting from the improper use of ARC numbers by noting that the royalty lines
label: BODY

text: were rejected by MMS' computer and MMS had to change the ARC numbers on each lines to 38 before
label: BODY

text: reentering the data.  MMS states that by correcting those line items itself, rather than returning the report to
label: BODY

text: Exxon, it prevented Exxon's being assessed late reporting or interest charges.
label: BODY

text: MMS asserts that Exxon had actual notice that ARC 34 should not be used with TC 01 and TC
label: BODY

text: 06 because MMS had corrected this same mistake
label: BODY

text: on Exxon's October 1984 Form MMS-2014.  MMS contends that it made the necessary corrections and sent
label: BODY

text: the original and one copy of the Royalty Rejected Line Detail Report to Exxon, with instructions to retain
label: BODY

text: the copy for its records and to sign, date, and return the original to MMS with the statement:  "I have
label: BODY

text: examined the changes and agree they are accurate and complete."  MMS states that the original was signed
label: BODY

text: by Ms. Susan Handley
label: BODY

text: on November 28, 1984, and returned to MMS, and indicates that a copy of
label: BODY

text: the signed report is in the official file.  MMS contends that this signed acknowledgement demonstrates
label: BODY

text: Exxon's knowledge of the incompatibility of ARC 34 and TC 01 and TC 06.
label: BODY

text: MMS further contends that the 1982 Payor Handbook clearly identified ARC 34 as a code to be
label: BODY

text: used only when adjusting allowances, while TC 01
label: BODY

text: and TC 06 are equally clearly identified as involving royalty transactions.  Therefore MMS concludes that
label: BODY

text: it gave Exxon sufficient notice that the use of ARC 34 with TC 01 and TC 06 was incorrect.
label: BODY

text: In sum, MMS argues that the lines on Form MMS-2014 were incorrectly completed; 30 CFR
label: BODY

text: 218.40(b) and (c) (1986) 4/ authorized it to assess
label: BODY

text: 4/  MMS recognizes that 30 CFR 218.40 was revised in 1987 but states that Exxon would have been assessed
label: BODY

text: the $10,000 maximum under the revised regulation as well as under the 1986 regulation (Answer at 3 n.1).
label: BODY

text: 113 IBLA 204
label: BODY

text: IBLA 88-181
label: BODY

text: Exxon $10,000 for the erroneous reporting; and, therefore, the Deputy Director's decision must be affirmed.
label: BODY

text: [1]  As an initial matter, we are troubled by MMS' failure to give Exxon a sufficient explanation
label: BODY

text: of the basis for its conclusion that Exxon had notice of the incompatibility of ARC 34 and TC 01 and TC 06
label: BODY

text: prior to addressing that issue in its answer to Exxon's statement of reasons in this appeal.  It is not enough
label: BODY

text: that MMS ensures that its decision is supported by a rational basis.  The basis for that decision must be stated
label: BODY

text: in the written decision and demonstrated in the administrative record accompanying the decision.  Eddleman
label: BODY

text: Community Property Trust, 106 IBLA 376, 377 (1989); Roger K. Ogden, 77 IBLA 4, 7, 90 I.D 481, 483
label: BODY

text: (1983).  The recipient of a decision deserves a reasoned and factual explanation of the rationale for the
label: BODY

text: decision, and must be given some basis for understanding it and accepting it or, alternatively, for appealing
label: BODY

text: and disputing it.  Eddleman Community Property Trust, supra; Southern Union Exploration Co., 51 IBLA
label: BODY

text: 89, 92 (1980) (and cases cited therein).
label: BODY

text: It is readily apparent from Exxon's submissions on appeal that Exxon did not know that the
label: BODY

text: October 1984 Form MMS-2014 corrections were the basis for the MMS holding that Exxon had prior notice.
label: BODY

text: The Deputy Director's sole explanation for his finding that "[t]he record supports the finding that Exxon had
label: BODY

text: been notified of the incompatibility of TC 01 and ARC 34"
label: BODY

text: is his statement that "[t]he Fiscal Accounting Division further states
label: BODY

text: that Exxon was notified in November 1984 that this type of reporting was inappropriate" (Decision at 2).
label: BODY

text: This statement gives no clue regarding
label: BODY

text: how Exxon was given notice, what constituted that notice, or how that document placed Exxon on notice,
label: BODY

text: and does not provide an adequate explanation for his determination.
label: BODY

text: Our concern goes further than noting that the Deputy Director's decision fails to sufficiently
label: BODY

text: apprise Exxon of the basis for the notice conclusion.  The Fiscal Accounting Division field report which was
label: BODY

text: the principal source for the MMS determination that Exxon had notice of the incompatibility of ARC 34 and
label: BODY

text: TC 01 and TC 06 was never made available
label: BODY

text: to Exxon.  Exxon was prejudiced by MMS' failure to provide necessary information concerning the basis for
label: BODY

text: its decision.  See Southern Union Exploration Co., supra at 93.  However, as will be seen, our resolution
label: BODY

text: of this appeal moots the question of how to remedy this prejudice.
label: BODY

text: [2]  The regulations in effect when Exxon filed its Form MMS-2014 authorized MMS to assess
label: BODY

text: $10 per day "for each report received by the designated due date but which is incorrectly completed."
label: BODY

text: 30 CFR 218.40(b) (1986).  The regulations further defined a report "as each line item on a Form
label: BODY

text: MMS-2014."  30 CFR 218.40(c) (1986).  Thus MMS clearly has the authority to assess Exxon for reporting
label: BODY

text: errors, and Exxon does not challenge that general authority.  Rather, Exxon contends that it did not err when
label: BODY

text: using ARC 34 with TC 01 and TC 06 because, based on the information it had, its use of that ARC number
label: BODY

text: was reasonable and appropriate.
label: BODY

text: Appendix B.4 of the 1982 Handbook provides the following descriptions for the relevant
label: BODY

text: adjustment reason codes:
label: BODY

text: 113 IBLA 205
label: BODY

text: IBLA 88-181
label: BODY

text: Code 34  Adjustments for Allowances - To adjust royalties as a result of a retroactive
label: BODY

text: allowance determination by Minerals Management Service (MMS).
label: BODY

text: Code 38  Other Adjustments - To adjust line entries that were previously reported with
label: BODY

text: coding or typographical errors when
label: BODY

text: the adjustment does not result in the payment of additional royalties.  [Emphasis
label: BODY

text: supplied.]
label: BODY

text: (1982 Oil and Gas Payor Handbook at B.4.2).  Exxon notes that its adjustments were not made because of
label: BODY

text: previous typographical or coding errors but were the result of retroactive transportation allowance
label: BODY

text: adjustments approved by MMS, and contends that MMS' descriptions of ARC 34 and ARC 38 support
label: BODY

text: Exxon's initial determination that ARC 34 was the appropriate code to use.  On the other hand, MMS argues
label: BODY

text: that the code for adjustments for allowances cannot be used for royalty value lines.
label: BODY

text: Often appellants will argue that a regulation is vague.  In many of those cases we have stated that
label: BODY

text: a regulation should be sufficiently clear that there is no basis for an oil and gas lessee's noncompliance with
label: BODY

text: the regulation before that regulation is interpreted to the detriment of a lessee.  See, e.g., Dennis W. Belnap,
label: BODY

text: 112 IBLA 243 (1989); Beard Oil Co., 97 IBLA 66 (1987); James M. Chudnow, 82 IBLA 262 (1984); Charles
label: BODY

text: J. Rydzewski, 55 IBLA 373, 88 I.D. 627 (1981); Wallace S. Bingham, 21 IBLA 266, 82 I.D. 337 (1975);
label: BODY

text: Mary I. Arata, 4 IBLA 201, 78 I.D. 397 (1971);
label: BODY

text: A. M. Shaffer, 73 I.D. 293 (1966).  If a regulation is ambiguous, any
label: BODY

text: doubt as to its meaning should be resolved favorably to the lessee.  Wallace S. Bingham, supra; Mary I.
label: BODY

text: Arata, supra; A. M. Shaffer, supra.
label: BODY

text: The need for clarity is even more imperative when MMS attempts to base a significant monetary
label: BODY

text: assessment on a lessee's failure to properly apply provisions of the Oil and Gas Payor Handbook because that
label: BODY

text: Handbook lacks the force and effect of law enjoyed by a statute or regulation.  See Mesa Petroleum Co.,
label: BODY

text: An examination of the descriptions of ARC 34 and ARC 38, as found
label: BODY

text: in the 1982 Handbook leaves little doubt that those descriptions do not unambiguously inform a payor that
label: BODY

text: ARC 34 cannot be used with TC 01 and TC 06.  In fact, those descriptions actually support Exxon's choice
label: BODY

text: of ARC 34 instead of ARC 38.  As can be seen, MMS' description of ARC 38 clearly states that ARC 38 is
label: BODY

text: to be used to adjust line entries that
label: BODY

text: were previously reported with coding or typographical errors.  Exxon was attempting to report adjustments
label: BODY

text: to its transportation allowance figures following MMS approval of its actual transportation costs, an entry
label: BODY

text: much closer to "a result of a retroactive allowance determination by Minerals Management Service (MMS)"
label: BODY

text: than an adjustment for "line entries that were previously reported with coding or typographical errors."  A
label: BODY

text: search of the Handbook for a proper code for the entry reported by Exxon could logically
label: BODY

text: 113 IBLA 206
label: BODY

text: IBLA 88-181
label: BODY

text: lead to the selection of ARC 34.  In addition we find nothing which can be construed as explicitly instructing
label: BODY

text: a payor that it is inappropriate to use ARC 34 with TC 01 and TC 06.  Accordingly, we find that, although
label: BODY

text: Exxon
label: BODY

text: may have erroneously used ARC 34 with TC 01 and TC 06, the MMS Handbook is ambiguous, and the doubt
label: BODY

text: as to the proper use of ARC 34 should be resolved in Exxon's favor.
label: BODY

text: We deem it unnecessary to consider whether the Handbook ambiguity would relieve Exxon of the
label: BODY

text: responsibility for using the proper ARC number if it had actual prior notice that it was improper to use ARC
label: BODY

text: 34 for the transactions reported.  After review of the evidence before us, we are not persuaded by MMS'
label: BODY

text: argument that Exxon had actual notice that its use of ARC 34 was wrong.  The only evidence in the record
label: BODY

text: supporting this argument consists of three sample pages of the Royalty Rejected Line Detail Report prepared
label: BODY

text: in response to Exxon's October 1984 Form MMS-2014, and attached as an exhibit to the Fiscal Accounting
label: BODY

text: Division field report.  Although one of those pages does contain a signed acknowledgement that
label: BODY

text: the changes are accurate and complete, the report itself merely states "INCORRECT REASON CODE FOR
label: BODY

text: THIS TRANSACTION," and provides no explanation whatsoever for this conclusion.  We also note that,
label: BODY

text: when preparing this report, MMS changed some of the ARC's from 34 to 00 and others to 38.
label: BODY

text: There is no explanation whatsoever for this conclusion, and no statement that ARC 34 is incompatible with
label: BODY

text: TC 01 and TC 06.  We therefore reverse the assessments based on line item entries found to be incorrect for
label: BODY

text: that reason only.
label: BODY

text: We note that the ambiguities in the 1982 Oil and Gas Payor Handbook leading to this appeal no
label: BODY

text: longer exist.  MMS substantially revised the Handbook in September 1986, and the current Handbook
label: BODY

text: discusses the usage
label: BODY

text: of the various transaction codes and lists the adjustment reason codes that may be used with each transaction
label: BODY

text: code.  ARC 34 is not listed for use with either TC 01 or TC 06.  (Volume II 1986 Oil and Gas Payor
label: BODY

text: Handbook at 3-27 and 3-103).  The Handbook also contains revised descriptions of ARC 34 and ARC 38:
label: BODY

text: ARC 34 is to be used "[t]o adjust an allowance as a result of a retroactive allowance determination by MMS,"
label: BODY

text: while ARC 38 is to be used "[t]o make adjustments that are MMS-mandated but do not fall within one
label: BODY

text: of the categories above and are not audit related" (Volume II 1986 Oil
label: BODY

text: and Gas Payor Handbook at 4-14 and A3-4).  Thus the requisite clarity of instruction now exists.
label: BODY

text: Exxon has not challenged the assessment for reporting unnecessary lines with no quantities and
label: BODY

text: values.  We affirm the assessments for
label: BODY

text: those reporting errors.  We note that 30 CFR 218.40(b) was revised in
label: BODY

text: 1987 to permit assessments of an amount not to exceed $10 for each incorrect report.  The current regulations
label: BODY

text: also authorize MMS to periodically establish the assessment amount for each reporting error based
label: BODY

text: on its experience with costs and improper reporting, and provide for the publication of notice of the
label: BODY

text: assessment amounts in the Federal Register.  30 CFR 218.40(e).  On July 22, 1987, MMS published a notice
label: BODY

text: establishing the following assessment schedule for erroneous royalty reporting:  $5 per line for 1-100
label: BODY

text: erroneous lines; $8 per line for 101-500 erroneous lines;
label: BODY

text: 113 IBLA 207
label: BODY

text: IBLA 88-181
label: BODY

text: and $10 per line for over 500 erroneous lines.  52 FR 27593 (July 22, 1987).  MMS should apply the revised
label: BODY

text: regulation and assessment schedule
label: BODY

text: in its determination of the proper amount of charges for the incorrect lines.  See Conoco, Inc., 102 IBLA 230
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, pursuant to the authority delegated to the Board of Land Appeals by the Secretary
label: BODY

text: of the Interior, 43 CFR 4.1, the decision appealed from is affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded
label: BODY

text: for further action consistent with this decision.
label: BODY
